content: The Act may be cited as the "Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit Improvement Act of 1999" and involves amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically focusing on modifications of the Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit. The "Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit Improvement Act of 1999" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to define a qualified domestic corporation as one actively conducting business in Puerto Rico, either under an existing credit claimant status or in an eligible line of business. The "Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit Improvement Act of 1999" defines a qualified domestic corporation as one actively conducting business in Puerto Rico, excluding those with an election under section 936(a)(4)(B)(iii) after December 31, 1996. The application is on a separate line of business basis. The "Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit Improvement Act of 1999" defines a qualified domestic corporation as one actively conducting business in Puerto Rico, excluding those with an election under section 936(a)(4)(B)(iii) after December 31, 1996. The application is on a separate line of business basis, with subsection (g) detailing how the credit applies to each substantial line of business of the corporation. Rules are established for the allocation of income, expenses, and allowances for eligible lines of business including manufacturing, agriculture, forestry, and fishing. The text discusses the repeal of the base period cap for the allowance of credit in certain lines of business, including manufacturing, agriculture, forestry, and fishing. It also mentions the amendment of the applicability date for the credit. The text discusses amendments to section 30A, including changing the effective date from January 1, 2006, to January 1, 2009. It also includes conforming amendments related to Puerto Rico and definitions for qualified income taxes and wages. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998. SEC. 3. COMPARABLE TREATMENT FOR OTHER ECONOMIC ACTIVITY CREDIT. Section 936(j)(2)(A) is amended to allow domestic corporations conducting business in possessions other than Puerto Rico to claim the economic activity credit for eligible lines of business. The economic activity credit is allowed for taxable years between 1995 and 2002 for domestic corporations conducting eligible lines of business in possessions other than Puerto Rico, with an exception for corporations electing reduced credit. The economic activity credit is allowed for taxable years between 1995 and 2002 for domestic corporations conducting eligible lines of business in possessions other than Puerto Rico. Section 936(j) is amended to apply separately to each substantial line of business of the corporation for the credit under subsection (a)(1)(A). The Secretary will prescribe rules for the allocation of income, gain, deduction, and loss for determining taxable income under subsection (a)(1)(A) and for the allocation of wages. The text discusses the allocation of wages, fringe benefits, and depreciation allowances for applying limitations under subsection (a)(4)(A) in eligible lines of business such as manufacturing, agriculture, forestry, and fishing. Additionally, it mentions amendments regarding new lines of business in Section 936(j)(9)(B). The text discusses limitations on new lines of business added after October 13, 1995, and defines substantial lines of business based on industry classification codes. The text discusses the repeal of the base period cap for the economic activity credit, allowing existing credit claimants to claim the credit for taxable years between 1998 and 2006, with limitations on taxable income based on adjusted base period income. The text discusses amendments to various sections related to income and tax credits, including changes to the applicable years for claiming credits and adjustments to income calculations. The text discusses amendments to Section 936(j)(8)(A) for applicable possessions, specifying changes in the application of tax rules for certain taxable years. Amendments to Section 936(j)(8)(A) for applicable possessions involve changes in tax rules for specific taxable years, effective after December 31, 1998. The amendment for new lines of business applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
